slides.title: Welcome
slides.content:
## Food Safety Level 2 (UK)

This course covers the essentials of food safety: the law, your duties, hazards, and how to keep food safe.

### What you'll learn
- **The law** – Food Safety Act 1990, hygiene regulations, and who enforces them.
- **Your duties** – As a food handler and as a manager.
- **Due diligence** – Records that prove you took reasonable steps.
- **Hazards** – Biological, chemical, physical – and how to control them.
- **Safe practices** – Temperature, storage, cleaning, and personal hygiene.

Use **Next** to move through the course.

slides.title: Why Food Safety Law Matters
slides.content:
## UK Food Law

UK food law is built around the **Food Safety Act 1990** and the **Food Hygiene Regulations**. They exist to protect consumers from illness and to keep businesses trading safely.

### Everyone's responsibility
Regulators expect everyone on shift to understand the basics: keep food safe, record what you do, and raise issues quickly. That duty applies whether you prep, cook, serve, or supervise.

slides.title: Who Does What
slides.content:
## Roles and Duties

**Food handlers** must:
- Follow documented safe methods every time.
- Stay away from food prep if ill and report symptoms.
- Keep equipment, surfaces, and storage clean and organised.

**Managers** must ensure safe methods exist, staff are trained, and monitoring proves controls work.

**Environmental Health Officers (EHOs)** inspect premises, behaviour, and records. They can issue enforcement notices, close businesses, or prosecute.

slides.title: Due Diligence
slides.content:
## Proving You Took Reasonable Steps

**Due diligence** means being able to show you took all reasonable precautions. In practice:
- Complete temperature and cleaning checks accurately.
- Sign off corrective actions when something is out of spec.
- Keep supplier and traceability paperwork so it can be produced quickly.

If something goes wrong, solid records show the business acted responsibly.

start.text: Who is responsible for recording fridge temperatures daily?

options.label: The food handler doing the check (or whoever is assigned).

wrong.text: ❌ **Incorrect.** Temperature checks are often done by food handlers. The manager ensures they happen and are recorded – but the person doing the check is responsible for completing it correctly.

correct.text: ✅ **Correct.** The person doing the check must record it accurately. Due diligence depends on reliable, signed records.

slides.title: Biological Hazards
slides.content:
## Bacteria, Viruses, Moulds

**Bacteria** (e.g. Salmonella, E. coli, Listeria) grow in food when conditions allow. They need **food**, **moisture**, **warmth**, and **time**.

**Viruses** (e.g. Norovirus) don't grow in food but can be spread by people and surfaces. Good personal hygiene and handwashing are vital.

**Moulds** spoil food and some produce harmful toxins. Store food correctly and discard spoiled items.

slides.title: Chemical and Physical Hazards
slides.content:
## Chemical
Cleaning products, pesticides, or allergens can contaminate food. Store chemicals away from food, follow COSHH, and never use food containers for chemicals.

## Physical
Foreign bodies: glass, plastic, metal, hair, pests. Control measures include good hygiene, pest control, and careful handling and packaging.

start.text: You've chopped raw chicken on a board. You need to prepare a salad. What do you do?

options.label: Wipe the board and use it for the salad.
Use a different, clean board (or wash and sanitise the board first).

wrong.text: ❌ **Incorrect.** Raw meat can contain harmful bacteria. A quick wipe does not remove them. You must use a separate board or wash and sanitise thoroughly before re-use.

correct.text: ✅ **Correct.** Separate equipment or proper cleaning and sanitising prevents cross-contamination from raw to ready-to-eat food.

modules.title: Temperature, Storage, and Personal Hygiene
modules.description: Safe temperatures, storage, and hygiene practices.

slides.title: The Danger Zone
slides.content:
## 8–63°C

Bacteria multiply quickly between **8°C and 63°C** (the danger zone). Keep cold food below 8°C and hot food above 63°C. Cool hot food quickly and store chilled.

**Key temperatures:**
- Fridge: 0–5°C (or follow your policy).
- Freezer: -18°C or below.
- Hot holding: 63°C or above.
- Reheating: 82°C (or follow your policy).

slides.title: Personal Hygiene
slides.content:
## Handwashing and Behaviour

**Handwashing**: Before handling food, after raw meat, after breaks, after touching face or hair. Use soap and warm water; dry with disposable towels.

**Illness**: Don't handle food if you have vomiting, diarrhoea, or certain infections. Report symptoms to your manager.

**Clothing**: Clean protective clothing, no jewellery (or limited as per policy), hair tied back.

slides.title: Cleaning Schedules
slides.content:
## What, When, How

Cleaning schedules say **what** to clean, **when**, and **how**. Complete them as required and sign them off. This is due diligence evidence.

**Clean then sanitise** for food contact surfaces. Store chemicals safely and use them according to instructions (COSHH).

slides.title: Inspections and Enforcement
slides.content:
## When EHOs Visit

They inspect behaviour, records, and premises. They can:
- Give advice and demand improvements.
- Issue **enforcement notices** (legal requirements with deadlines).
- **Close** unfit premises.
- **Prosecute** businesses and individuals.

Good records and consistent safe practices protect you and the business.
